awd_titl_txt: CPS:Small: Imposing Recovery Period for Battery Health Monitoring, Prognosis, and Optimization
awd_abstract_narration:
The prevalence of battery-powered systems such as electric vehicles, smartphones, and IoT devices has made batteries crucial to everyone's daily life and business. Battery health, however, degrades over time, not only decreasing system reliability such as unexpected system shutoffs, but also causing overheating/gassing which, in turn, increases safety risks such as thermal runaway or even battery fire/explosion. To address these problems, we must monitor, prognose, and optimize battery health throughout the physical system life. However, existing battery management systems (BMSes) are usually treated as complementary system components attached/embedded to/in batteries, and are unable to make optimal health management decisions adaptively based on system dynamics or user requirements. Our approach tightly integrates the cyber (battery management software) and the physical (sensing of battery state) to enable significant improvements in battery life and performance. The research, outreach, and education activities of this project will have broader impacts on the CPS research and industry communities, bridging the gap between them, providing environment-friendly solutions, increasing the awareness of CPS, and developing skilled human resources. It will also make significant economical and environmental impacts by enabling longer battery life and improved performance. 

This project will develop R-AWARE, a recovery period-assisted battery health management that schedules system operation while considering both system/user requirements and battery health. R-AWARE will improve battery health via relaxation-aware battery scheduling of battery charging/discharging, and recovery-based thermal control. It will advance the science of CPS by uncovering a thorough understanding of battery recovery and exploiting it via a recovery-aware scheduler during system operation. Specifically, R-AWARE is grounded on a thorough understanding of the physical recovery effects on battery health -- a new dimension for system optimization existing BMSes fail to exploit. R-AWARE then takes a cyber-physical approach for battery health management by adapting its decisions based on various physical properties of batteries/systems/environment. Finally, R-AWARE improves battery health by exploiting the opportunities offered by user behavior/requirements without degrading user experience. A performance goal of the project is to enable a 40% slowdown in battery health degradation.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit. This project comprehensively explored the impacts of battery relaxation on the aging process of batteries. Based on this understanding, opportunities to estimating battery health, slowing down battery degradation, and predicting and maximizing the remaining usable battery capacity have been examined, with the concomitant algorithms designed and experimentally tested. All these designs are user- and temperature-aware, i.e., these opportunities of optimizing battery performance are explored without degrading user experience and in consideration of temperature’s impacts on batteries. A by-production of this research is the models and algorithms allowing the use of batteries as thermometers to monitor the temperature of surrounding ambient.

This project leads to 9 research papers as summarized below.

  1. L. He and K. G. Shin, Fingerprinting battery health using relaxing voltages. In ACM e-Energy'23, 2023.
  2. L. He, Y. Lee, and K. G. Shin, Using Mobile Device Batteries as Thermometers, GetMobile: Mobile Computing and Communications, vol. 25, issue 1, 2021.
  3. E. Kim, Y. Lee, L. He, K. G. Shin, and J. Lee. Power guarantee for electric systems using real-time scheduling. IEEE Transactions on Parallel and Distributed Systems, 31(8):1783–1798, 2020.
  4. Youngmoon Lee, Liang He, Eugene Kim, and Kang G. Shin. Causes and fixes of unexpected phone shutoffs. In MobiSys’20, 2020.
  5. Liang He, Youngmoon Lee, and Kang Shin. Mobile device batteries as thermometers. In UbiComp’20, 2020.
  6. Liang He, Youngmoon Lee, Eugene Kim, and Kang G. Shin. Environment-aware estimation of battery state-of-charge for mobile devices. In ICCPS’19, 2019.
  7. Eugene Kim, Bin Wu, Kang Shin, Jinkyu Lee, and Liang He. Adaptive battery diagnosis/prognosis for efficient operation. In ACM e-Energy’19, 2019.
  8. Liang He, Linghe Kong, Yu Gu, Cong Liu, Tian He, and Kang G. Shin. Extending battery system operation via adaptive reconfiguration. ACM Transactions on Sensor Networks, 15(11), 2019.
  9. L. He, Z. Yang, Y. Gu, C. Liu, T. He, and K. G. Shin. SoH-aware reconfiguration in battery packs. IEEE Transactions on Smart Grid, 9(4):3727–3735, 2018.

Also, 8 US/international patents have been obtained/filed based on the research results. A spin-off startup company, called Batteries Beyond Batteries Corp., is incorporated to accelerate the commercialization of the developed technologies.

  1. Kang Shin and Liang He. "User aware charging algorithm that reduces battery fading", US Patent Application No. 15/984843, granted, 02/2022.
  2. Kang Shin and Liang He. “Method To Estimate Battery Health For Mobile Devices Based On Relaxing Voltages”, US Patent Application No. 16/605893, granted, 08/2021.
  3. Kang Shin and Liang He. “Method To Estimate Battery Health For Mobile Devices Based On Relaxing Voltages”, China Patent Application No. 2018800314255, granted, 11/2019.
  4. Kang Shin and Liang He. “Method To Estimate Battery Health For Mobile Devices Based On Relaxing Voltages”, Japanese Patent Application No. 2020-506131, granted, 09/2022.
  5. Kang Shin and Liang He. “Method To Estimate Battery Health For Mobile Devices Based On Relaxing Voltages”, Korea Patent Application No. 10-2019-7033092, filed, 12/2018.
  6. Kang Shin and Liang He. “Method to Charge Lithium-Ion Batteries with User, Cell, and Temperature Awareness”, US patent Application No. 15/335556, granted, 05/2022.
  7. Kang Shin and Liang He. “Method to Charge Lithium-Ion Batteries with User, Cell, and Temperature Awareness”, British Patent Application No. 18145482, granted, 09/2018.
  8. Kang Shin and Liang He. “Method to Charge Lithium-Ion Batteries with User, Cell, and Temperature Awareness”, Korea Patent Application No. 10-2018-7028062, granted, 09/2018.

Broader Impacts. This project has supported 3 graduate students, one of whom joined Apple's battery management team after obtaining his Ph.D. This project has also offered research opportunities for 3 undergraduate students. The results of this project have been integrated into (under)graduate courses at UM and CU-Denver, i.e., EECS 373/473 (Embedded Systems), EECS 571 (Principles of Real-Time Computing), CSCI 3515 (Internet-of-Things), and CSCI-5575 (Cyber-Physical Systems). The results have been disseminated to the community via the following invited talks:

  1. Mobile Device Batteries as Thermometers, ACM UbiComp'20, online.
  2. Environment-aware estimation of battery state-of-charge for mobile devices, Montreal, Quebec, Canada, 2019.
  3. Adaptive battery diagnosis/prognosis for efficient operation, ACM e-Energy'19, Phoenix, AZ, USA, 2019.
  4. Batteries as Power Supply/Storage and Sensors, Nankai University, Tianjin China, 2019.
  5. Cognitive Battery Management, University of Colorado Boulder, CO, USA, 2017.
